title: How long will Mass. residents have to wait until their power is restored?
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Over 100,000 customers in Eastern Massachusetts are without power after a Monday blizzard caused extensive outages.
Eversource and National Grid warn power restoration for some could take until Thursday due to high winds and conditions.
Eversource reported 220,000 customers without power Tuesday afternoon, while National Grid restored power to 71,000 customers.

title: 15 prospects Patriots fans should know entering the 2026 NFL Combine
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots possess 11 picks in the 2026 NFL Draft, including the 31st overall selection, to enhance their roster.
Prospects like KC Concepcion, Zion Young, and Kenyon Sadiq are among potential targets for boosting offense and defense.
Scouting efforts focused on assessing talent at the 2026 NFL Combine in Indianapolis, targeting specific positional needs.

title: Malden school employee on leave after alleged ‘serious incident’ involving high school student
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: A Malden school employee is on leave following an alleged serious incident involving a high school student.
The employee works at Linden STEAM Academy; the incident is under investigation by Malden police.
No arrests or charges have been made; the alleged incident occurred outside of working hours.

title: These Mass. schools are closed for Wednesday, Feb. 25
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Schools in Massachusetts remain closed as areas recover from a historic snowstorm with up to three feet of snow.
Many closed school districts are located on the South Coast and South Shore, which experienced the heaviest snowfall.
Delayed openings include schools in Canton, King Philip Regional, Sharon, Walpole, and Wrentham.

title: MBTA to (mostly) resume normal weekday service after historic blizzard
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: MBTA plans to resume regular weekday service Wednesday except for the Fall River/New Bedford line with a modified schedule.
The Fall River/New Bedford line was the hardest hit by the storm, affecting its Commuter Rail service recovery.
Riders are advised to allow extra travel time and stay updated via MBTA alerts and social media channels.

title: Curran: Patriots could ‘explore options’ to potentially upgrade from Stefon Diggs
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots may explore options to upgrade from Stefon Diggs, owing to his $26.5 million cap hit in 2026.
Diggs had a successful 2025 season with New England, recording over 1,000 receiving yards and showing strong leadership.
Diggs' future with the team is uncertain due to potential contract restructuring and his age, turning 33 in November.

title: Mass. representatives, including minority whip, to skip State of the Union address
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Several Massachusetts representatives, including Katherine Clark, Ayanna Pressley, and Ed Markey, plan to skip the State of the Union address.
Katherine Clark criticizes Trump's health care cuts and ICE policies, choosing to engage with local constituents instead of attending the address.
Ayanna Pressley plans to uplift stories of detained immigrant children, while Ed Markey will attend the 'People's State of the Union' rally.

title: Will Charlie McAvoy, Jeremy Swayman be back in Bruins lineup when they resume play Thursday?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Boston Bruins await Charlie McAvoy and Jeremy Swayman's return after Team USA's gold medal win in Milano-Cortina.
Weather-related travel issues delayed McAvoy and Swayman's return from Milan, with stops in Miami and Washington, D.C.
Bruins face Columbus Blue Jackets on Thursday amid uncertainty over McAvoy and Swayman's availability for the game.

title: Could Trent Williams suddenly emerge as a free-agent target for Patriots?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots considering Trent Williams to fortify offensive line after struggles in Super Bowl LX.
Trent Williams, 37, may enter free agency if contract talks with 49ers stall, likely as top available tackle.
49ers could face $34 million dead cap hit if Williams is cut, with potential to spread the cost over two years.

title: Boston ends snow emergency parking ban; residents can use space savers until Thursday evening
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Boston lifted its snow emergency and parking ban at 6 p.m. Tuesday after clearing 4,620 cubic yards of snow.
Residents using discounted garages must remove their vehicles by 8 p.m. to avoid regular charges.
Space savers must be removed by 6 p.m. Thursday, with continued snow removal efforts planned throughout the week.
